Award.AwardTitle: Participant Support for the 8th Conference on Extreme Value Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract: This proposal provides partial support to the US participants of the 8th Conference on Extreme Value Analysis to be held on July 8--12, 2013 at the Fudan University, Shanghai, China, where PIs are members of Scientific committee and organizing committee. EVA conferences started in Gothenburg, Sweden in 1998, then they became regular meetings for researchers in extreme value analysis. The aim of these conferences is to bring together a diverse range of researchers, practitioners, and graduate students whose work is related to the analysis of extreme values in a broad sense.

In recent years, extreme events have been becoming more and more frequent and severe, and extreme events result in huge losses to our society. For example, the US now has been suffering from the biggest drought since 1956. How to model and predict such extreme events is of great importance. The major reason for this proposal is to provide partial support, mostly to graduate students and junior faculty from the United States, to boost the participation of US researchers, to improve the visibility and to encourage further research on extreme value analysis in the United States.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 8th Conference on Extreme Value Analysis was held from July 8 to 12, 2013 at the Fudan University, Shanghai, China and was supported under DMS-1258701.  This grant partially supported students and researchers in the US to participate in the conference. Through this support, students and young researchers gained experience in presenting research topics at an international conference. The conference brought together a diverse range of researchers, practitioners and graduate students whose work is related to the analysis of extreme values in a broad sense.

Broader Impact: The visibility of US research in extreme value theory has been improved too, so much so the conference will be held, only for the second time, in the US in 2015. There were 142 participants in which all but 28 gave presentations. Nineteen countries were represented.

Intellectual Merit: This conference promoted all probabilistic and statistical aspects of extreme value analysis and applications. Some research areas are in max- and sum-stable random field modeling, algebra and topology of random fields, hierarchical statistical models for extremes, and statistical measures for spatial extremes. These subjects have significant applications in insurance, finance, risk management, climate and atmospheric sciences, physics, biosciences, geosciences and hydrology just to name a few.
